column13: We spent a week at the beach in January in our second visit to this beautiful home. There are not a lot of stores or restaurants open but it is wonderful to be at the seashore at that time of year. However, winter in Maine can be tricky. We experienced a snow/ice storm which resulted in an area-wide power outage. The house has a Generac backup generator which did not turn on when the power went off. We contacted Olivia who immediately contacted an electrician and boiler repairman. We felt lucky that these very busy tradesmen were able to come over soon and remedy the problem, particularly since much of the area remained out of power for up to several days. Putting that experience behind us, we enjoyed a very peaceful stay and are grateful to Olivia for her prompt efforts to help us. We would not hesitate to stay here again.

column13: This was my third time staying in one of Mr. Szafranski’s units and the unit was just as great as the other two. Great and clean space, super comfy bed and great set up to work and relax. Walkable neighborhood close to VCU and restaurants/coffee shops. I enjoyed the space and neighborhood. I hope Mr. Szafranski appreciates returning customers like myself, although I couldn’t tell from his very canned and bland communications. I can live with that though because the space was as pictured and promised. But it would be nice to feel your returning business is appreciated! There was also another communication issue I was very disappointed with and still am (the power was out for a few hours one day; I wasn’t informed in advance although they were aware it would be out). My main disappointment was that I received a response about the issue 13 hours after I sent a message and it didn’t include any note of acknowledgment of my inconvenience. Even though the issue was out Mr. Szafranski’s control, a simple sorry for your inconvenience goes along with customer interactions. I did get in contact with his assistant during the power outage and he said he meant to tell me when I checked in the day prior. I understand we all are human and things slip our minds but again the disappointment was that Mr. Szafranski replied in the Vrbo app 13 hours later and just said we understand the power went out but thankfully it came back on in a few hours. Yes thankfully indeed and luckily I didn’t need to work early that day but Heaven help me if I had a ventilator or respirator that needed electricity. Again, just a simple “although this was out of our control, we are sorry for the inconvenience” would have went a long way. Put a bad taste in my mouth but I still rate them high (they emphasize that anything less than a 5 star rating “hurts” them) because the unit was so comfortable and served my purposes. Don’t know if I will stay again because I am not sure my business is appreciated but for other travelers considering Mr. Szafranski’s units, they are as pictured/described and are quite comfortable.

column13:
What can I say about Mike & April and their beautiful West Dover/Mount Snow accommodations, except absolutely, unequivocally fabulous. They are kind, generous, and communicative, and their home is perfect--clean, tidy, organized, well-suited for families, great local facilities, and close to the mountain (ski-on/off).

Why am I so glowing in my review? Well, we had a snafu in our original plans. Two families (4 adults and 6 young children) checked into a different house. One snowstorm later (great for skiing, less-so for our housing), our original home was without electricity, running water, or heat. The management company promised us we'd "be taken care of", but by 6 PM the power wasn’t on and the management company abdicated their responsibility--we were stuck and left homeless.

After a quick Vrbo search, we came upon Mike & April's abode. They quickly responded and lent a hand, made their home available that same night, and immediately got the house cleaned/prepped. Within hours, our travel group was nestled into Mike & April's warm, welcoming home.

The rest of our stay was blessedly uneventful with 4 comfortable nights at Mike & April's. It fit our 2 families easily, was well-maintained, and truly made our vacation! Throughout our time, Mike & April were available for anything we may have needed and made us feel welcome and at home.

All-in-all, I cannot recommend them more. Thank you Mike & April for saving our vacation and making it even better!!

We reluctantly decided to stay due to already paying. Once taken to the door he opened it, told us to take our shoes off as his wife had just “vacuumed “ the bright pink carpet 30yr old dirty carpet, took us up to the “room” in which looked like we were in a converted attic and we actually laughed the 2 days we were there as if we had a 1st college studio this would have been it!! The 1st night we plugged in our small foreman grill which blew a breaker and we had no electricity until the “host” fixed it. We then got a message saying to unplug the heater if we needed to use other power as it would happen again….not cool. The bathroom was a nightmare!!! Now “host” is saying the 30yr old bed was broken, which is a flat lie and charging us $1300! We should have trusted our gut instinct as we knew before even getting to the property something was off with this “host” and sure enough. He admitted to listening to us in our room in a text. This MIL suite is at the lower portion of a house, with a fully separate entry. It was really good to have a level entrance with no stairs! The electric fireplace was nice, WiFi/Internet great, parking was great, and owner communication was great!

The listing said full kitchen and we used the dishes, silverware, pots and pans, tea kettle, toaster, microwave, and dishwasher. We did not use the countertop oven. I appreciated knowing that it was a small refrigerator ahead of time, as it helped in planning what to bring/not bring. The listing I believe did say a stove, which was one of the reasons I selected it. What was in the kitchen was 2 burner ceramic/glass stovetop, which even with a users manual was a bit confusing for me to use. However in communicating with the owner my questions were cleared up. It might have been helpful to have pictures of the kitchen to see what was included. 

The weather when we were there was cold for the Seattle area so we used the wall thermostat/heaters and the space heaters. However we were also cooking at the same time on the stovetop and heating water in a tea kettle and the power went out in a portion of the kitchen and some outlets. To his credit, when we contacted the owner he quickly remedied the situation. 

We did not use the sunroom, but did enjoy the view of the creek, chickens, garden outside, and evergreen trees.

column11: A reputable rental site such as VRBO without electricity and heat should never be allowed in temperatures as cold as this.
column13:
Receiving our concerns and complaints did us no good while we stayed there. We complained regarding the heat and electricity not working from the 1st night. 

Being transparent would’ve been letting us know that there would not be efficient electricity and heat provided to all the rooms. There are basic expectations for a rental, such as a roof, electricity, heat, and walls. These are not items that any renter should “reach out and ask questions or be concerned about before booking” 
Should I have also reached out and asked before I arrived if there was a roof? Electricity and heat are basic needs that should have been met every time someone rents a home in a place as cold as Mammoth. Unless you specifically state in your description of the home that heat and electricity MAY NOT be available at all times, which it was not. 
I wish I looked at the reviews before I rented because I am obviously not the first person to complain of the exact same two things the breaker feeling, which means no electricity and heat not working properly. 

“Greatly apologizing my for the inconvenience and difficulties” of being cold and lacking electricity is not ok. “Promising to have this issue resolved in the future”does not help me, because I will never stay here again. Neither is “Feeling my great disappointment” 
We stayed there cold, and lacking electricity because there weren’t any other places to stay. 

Having basic necessities such as heat, and electricity in Mammoth is something that should not be “looked into” it should be mandatory and MUST at all times. We all left the house and weekend sniffling and feeling as if we were on the verge of being sick. 
A reputable rental site such as VRBO without electricity and heat should never be allowed in temperatures as cold as this. 

I would like to be fully refunded rather than apologized to. If not I will have no choice other than to further escalate my complaint, or speak to my attorney.

column13:
Listing photos look amazing and lots of things appear “pretty” but I had major issues from the moment I arrived until the moment I left. 

- I arrived on a Saturday, during a rain storm, to leaks in both master bedroom and living room (all over sofa). I immediately contacted owner who lives close by but instead of coming over to look, she instructed me to put pots out to collect dripping water and that a roofer would come by Monday. Monday it was fixed but she left the dirty leak collecting pots in the sink for me to clean myself. Had I been the owner, I would have left a bottle of nice wine and an apology note, not a pile of dirty pots for my renter to clean. 

- The dishwater is faulty and did not clean dishes, It would run, but the dishes were still filthy after a cycle. I am an adult and quite familiar with using dishwashers, the owner instead of coming by to see for herself decided to give me a lesson on how to work the dishwasher. Regardless, I can attest that after 5 cycles the dishes never got clean. So, I spent two weeks having to hand washing all the dirty dishes. 

- The power went out one night in the middle of the night and I had to contact the owner. Thankfully, it was restored fairly quickly but no utility contact/account info was given in her inadequate "welcome book", so I was unable to get updates as to when the power would return. 

- The garage door is controlled by a digital lock with code but the system is funky and gave me trouble a few times. Additionally the garage is very small. The front door digital lock with code is also difficult, it seems to time out and the only thing to do is wait 15 minutes for it to reset. I was locked out after midnight one night and the owner did not return my texts until 6am. This is a basic safety issue and for this reason alone the apartment should not be rented until it is corrected. 

- Finally, the washer and dryer are in a janky downstairs room which is very grimy. The washer/dryer is not listed in the "welcome book" forcing me to inquire (yet again) about their whereabouts and usage. 

- I travel and use short term rentals 6-8 times per year and this experience was pretty awful. Wendy the owner was “mostly” responsive but consistently condescending. She also offered no credit for any of the above issues. Well, she did offer to let me out of my contract a few days early but it wasn’t worth leaving at that point. 

- In conclusion, don't judge this book by its cover!

There were instructions in the manual provided about what to do in the event of a power outage, but I am surprised that there is not a generator on the property if power loss is a regular occurrence. We did receive a partial refund (even though the contract does state that the owners are not liable for power loss, among other things), which we did appreciate. Again, it is a lovely place, but maybe make sure you stay somewhere in the area that has a generator.

column13:
Wow, so much to say about such a short stay. Sigh...we booked this place for a ten night stay in Salt Lake over the Christmas and New Year holidays. We checked in on the 23rd and walked into an attic apartment with no heat. It was 28 degrees outside AND inside the place. We could literally see our breath, standing next to the bed. 

Once I discovered there was no power to the thermostat, I contacted the property manager who, up until the day of check-in, had been very communicative. He (Eddie) told me he had never heard of this problem and asked me to send him a picture of the thermostat, my name, and the address to the property where we were staying. Um, okay. I did that and he told me he would get back to me. Luckily we had family to meet and we were able to go to dinner somewhere that allowed us to keep our car running so the dogs didn't freeze. 

While we were still under the assumption that the heater would be fixed eventually, we bought a space heater at Costco ($90) and a bag of ice melt ($10) to try to remove the snow and ice that were frozen on the Excorcist-style metal staircase. Oh, a couple more fun facts - there was no lightbulb over the door at the top of the stairs and also no mat outside the door to keep from tracking everything onto the kitchen floor. 

I'm going to spare the frustrating story of my texts back and forth with Eddie about the heater not working, the neighbors trying to flip the breaker, and the property manager not being able to reach a technician because it was Christmas and just skip to the part where Eddie told me his solution was to cancel our reservation and issue a refund. Whaaaaaaat???

And so...we had no where to stay. On Christmas, with two big dogs and a truck full of the things needed to live life away from home for ten days. We ended up finding a place eventually, but had to pay another $1000+ on top of the $900 we had already paid to VRBO. 

Eddie told us on December 23rd that we would received a refund. We received it (after multiple texts and emails,) on January 5th. 

I understand this apartment is only used as a rental property. It's bare bones, which would have been fine if there had been heat. There were towels set out for us, so it looked like someone had prepared the place for our stay. Only no one had prepared. You would think if you were renting a property in the middle of winter, you would check to make sure the heater worked. Maybe they should actually visit the property once in a while?

We ran into a couple issues the first day due to a city-wide power outage as the generator didn't kick in right away. Property manager was very responsive and helped us work through everything. I cannot express enough how great the property manager was!
Beds were very comfortable, but there was only one thick/firm style of pillow that will not work for stomach sleepers.
Pool or ocean are both a 5 minute walk away. And you are in walking distance to a few different restaurants. Twisted Lime was my personal fave. Just make sure you aren't starving before you get to the restaurant as service is quite a bit slower than we are used to in Canada.

However, we didnt understand hurricane doors - you have to pull the handle up to make the door shut properly. We didn't figure this out until midstay, which lessened the noise.
We went with our two children, 10 and 12, and felt quite safe. 
You can take the #10 bus to downtown Nassau. Route goes along the coast and is about a 20 minute ride. Bus can be caught anywhere on the side of the main road by flagging them down. And when you want to get off, just say "bus stop". Fare is $1.50 per person. NOTE: Do NOT take the #10A is this route winds inland and takes significantly longer. Cabs were more expensive than we were expecting, and they charge additional for more than two people ($50 to downtown one way for 5 people).
Overall, a really great place to stay, but everything was significantly more expensive than we were expecting in the Bahamas.

column13: Property was a bit worn from comparison with the pictures. The property description proclaimed there were lounge chairs on the balcony overlooking the sea, when in actuality there were 4 plastic, hard, upright chairs that were not at all conducive to relaxation & a half-broken wooden table to place your drink on! We would have liked to spend more time on the balcony, but the chairs were too uncomfortable. The master bath shower area is cave-like & really needed a power vent to remove the moisture, but that was broken. The stove top is barely working, as the touch pad is so worn it is difficult to adjust the temperature & to turn on & off. The paint on the ceiling is peeling off in the common kitchen area, & the refrigerator water/ice machine with the filter is inop so no potable water. The condo has the absolute BEST location in the entire complex with direct access to the pools & the beach is just steps away. Good parking is available close to the front door & is by gated access only with guard 24/7. This poor condo needs some TLC and it would be absolutely awesome!! We enjoyed St Maarten and this building location gives easy driving access to both the French & Dutch side restaurants, and the airport, while providing a very peaceful & restful atmosphere. Just needs a little TLC!

column11: We lost power for 24 hours (we actually expected it to be longer), and Jenny had warned us it might cut out.
column13:
The important things first: Jenny is an excellent host, all communication was quick and easy. The house met all our needs and the location was what we were looking for (quiet, good space, and out-of-the-way). 

Caveat: we stayed Dec-Jan, winter months, no idea what summer is like in Rockaway Beach!

This is the longest we've stayed at a single place (almost 2 months), so we were wary, it was a big gamble. But, the house was a nice surprise. Great wifi, plenty of space for those rainy days when you can't go out, better than average tools in the kitchen, and deer, ducks, egrets, more birds, visiting the pond next door (literally, outside the porch). The neighborhood was quiet, the beach is walking distance (we did that a lot, it's a great walking beach), there's hiking in the hill to the back (did that a lot too, no seems to make use of it, even though hikers are welcome, never saw anyone else there). 

We even survived the huge storm of December just fine, although things outside didn't fare as well (BBQ grill, chairs and table went flying). 64mph winds will do that! We lost power for 24 hours (we actually expected it to be longer), and Jenny had warned us it might cut out. Either we lucked out or things have gotten much better in Rockaway, but that was the only time we lost power.

As for Rockaway Beach, if you're looking for restaurants and shopping in the winter... not gonna happen! It's a typical tourist town, beholden to the summer months, so not much open. It's exactly what we expected, so no surprise. Stock up in Tillamook or visit Astoria and the Costco, you should be good to go.

If you're looking for a clean, comfortable, quiet place (in the winter, at least), with a great host, this is an excellent house.

column13: We came on a Friday night and everything was lovely. The door wasn’t locked (the deadbolt seemed like it hasn’t properly engaged). The beds were very creeky but comfortable. We woke up and made breakfast and then the power went out. We ate breakfast and then found the breaker box and flipped the breakers. The lights came back on. We thought everything was good after that but then we went to wash the dishes from our breakfast and the water wasn’t working. We contacted the company, bought a few gallons of water so that we could flush the toilets, and then went to the beach. The beach is not a short path away. It is a rather long road down several streets. We kept asking people we passed where the path was and they laughed and said we were better off driving. When we came back from the beach we started to make lunch and realized that even though the lights were on, the oven hadn’t come back on. So we went out to lunch. When we came back from lunch we put the babies down for a nap. We adjusted the heaters in the rooms and found out that the heaters weren’t working (neither the cadets in the wall or the ductless system that was lighting up like it was on but no air was coming out). We really wanted to stay and did enjoy our first night there, but we couldn’t figure out why the water, oven and heaters weren’t working. At that point we decided to end our trip early and go home to make sure it was safe for our babies who we were worried about getting too cold without heat. After we packed everything up, my husband checked that the door was locked and the door handle came off.

column13: Pics looks amazing and lots of things appear “pretty” but I had MAJOR issues from the moment I arrived until the moment I left. I arrived on a Saturday, during a rain storm, to leaks in both master bedroom and living room all over sofa. I immediately contacted owner who apparently lives close. Instead of coming over to look right away she instructed me to put pots out to collect water and roofer would come Monday. Monday it was fixed BUT she actually left me the pots in the sink to clean myself!! Unreal. I would have left a bottle of good wine if it was my place! The dishwater did not clean dishes adequately. I am 46 and very familiar with using dishwashers, since the owner seemed to think I needed a review, and can attest that after 5 cycles my dishes were not clean. The power went out one night in the middle of the night and I had to contact the owner. Thankfully it was restored fairly quickly but no utility info was given in her shitty welcome book. The tv in the bedroom did not work initially. The garage door is funky and gave me trouble a few times and is VERY small. The front door punch code is also a pain in the ass and I was locked out after midnight one night and the owner did not return my texts until 6am. Not ok and not safe. Additionally, the washer and dryer are in a janky room downstairs and very grimy. It also isn’t listed in her welcome book and I needed to inquire about their whereabouts and usage. I travel a ton and this experience was fairly awful. Wendy the owner was “mainly” responsive but super condescending and in no way offered any kick back due to my issues. She offered to let me out of my contract a few days early but it wasn’t worth me leaving at that point. I do not recommend!!!
